Award.AwardTitle: Application of Rayleigh-Based, Multi-Element Coral Thermometry to Constrain Atlantic Sea Surface Temperatures During the Coldest Period of the Little Ice Age
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed work will test and apply a new technique for reconstructing sea surface temperature (SST) at seasonal resolution using coral skeletons. The technique, called Rayleigh-based multi-element (RBME) thermometry, uses multiple element ratios to isolate the SST signal from other factors affecting coral skeleton composition. To quantify the method?s accuracy and reproducibility, RBME thermometry will be used to reconstruct SSTs from four species of modern extra-tropical and tropical Atlantic corals in ~50-year sections for which instrumental temperature records are available. The technique will then be applied to fossil corals of the same four species to generate seasonal-scale SST records for the coldest period of the Little Ice Age (1650?1700). These records will lead to an improved understanding of the amplitude and spatial distribution of SST change in the Atlantic during a climate anomaly that is not fully understood.

This research will advance our capacity to reconstruct past changes in the ocean?climate system, and thereby to understand how this system may change in the future. The project will enhance research infrastructure by developing computer code to make the RBME technique accessible to the broader scientific community. A graduate student will be supported through the WHOI/MIT Joint Program, and undergraduate students will be involved via WHOI?s Summer Fellowship, Winter Internship, Minority Fellowship, and Guest Student programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Paleoclimate records, natural archives of environmental conditions on timescales longer than the instrumental record, are powerful tools to better understand climate sensitivity and temperature variability. The skeletons of long-lived, massive coral colonies have the potential to produce high-resolution records of past tropical ocean temperatures. A thin layer of living coral tissue continually precipitates an aragonite (CaCO3) skeleton allowing the coral colony to grow upward and preserving its older skeleton below. Large coral colonies can live for hundreds of years and provide continuous paleoceanographic records at subannual resolution.  Geochemical coral proxies take advantage of corals’ biologically mediated calcification of their aragonite skeletons from seawater. The coral polyp transports seawater into a calcifying space and precipitates aragonite from the fluid contained in the calcifying space. While aragonite is composed almost entirely of CaCO3, some minor elements (e.g., Sr, Mg, U) are incorporated as well. This process involves two major controls on the abundance of minor elements in coral aragonite: Rayleigh fractionation and temperature. The concentration of a given minor element in the precipitated aragonite will differ from that in the calcifying fluid and can be described over time by the Rayleigh distillation equation. The distillation process produces an an inverse relationship between Sr/Ca and the amount of aragonite precipitated. The strength of the Rayleigh fractionation signal varies among coral colonies at a single site and within individuals on subannual scales. The second control on minor element abundance is the influence of temperature on the incorporation of minor elements into the coral aragonite skeleton. This effect varies from element to element but for Sr/Ca leads to an inverse correlation with temperature.  Funds from this grant supported the development, refinement and application of coral thermometry based on the Rayleigh model that combines information from multiple element ratios to reconstruct temperature (Rayleigh-based multielement (RBME) thermometry).  Specifically, we combined information from Sr/Ca and U/Ca ratios in coral skeleton (Sr-U thermometry) to reconstruct sea surface temperatures in the western tropical Atlantic during the Little Ice Age.  Sr-U thermometry is conceptually based upon a forward model for biomineralization that correctly predicts relationship between skeleton Sr/Ca and U/Ca. While coral skeleton Sr/Ca is sensitive to both temperature and Rayleigh fractionation, coral skeleton U/Ca is sensitive only to Rayleigh fractionation through changes in calcifying fluid carbonate ion concentration ([CO32-]). Thus a positive correlation between coral skeleton Sr/Ca and U/Ca at a single temperature is produced by Rayleigh fractionation. Among different corals, different Sr/Ca values corresponding to a single benchmark U/Ca of 1.1 mmol/mol are expected to reflect temperature alone.  Application of a global Sr-U calibration derived from 19 corals from five genera to two coral cores from Puerto Rico shows that Sr-U replicates well between the two cores and is able to capture the mean sea surface temperature, trend, and multidecadal variability well over the entire 20th century.  Sr-U was also used to reconstruct sea surface temperatures at Puerto Rico during a cool period known as the Little Ice Age (~1400-1850 CE) a recent episode of centennial scale climate change.  Our Sr-U results show that over the period 1465-1560 the region was 1.1 ± 0.6 °C cooler than the 1958-1988 mean, but within error of early 20th century sea surface temperature at this site. Critically, several periods of warmth, equivalent to the 1958-1988 mean, occurred during a solar minimum that is widely believed to have been a cool period of the Little Ice Age.  Funds from this grant supported the PhD research of female graduate student.  Results from this study were reported in five peer-reviewed papers published in top journals.
